commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Add requires on python >= 3.6 to setup.cfg so that pypi and pip
  know about the requirement
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Update classifiers
- Update requirements, no need for python_version anymore
- Use newer openstackdocstheme version
- Add basepython to tox.ini

Change-Id: I4b731354119ebc3a7519da420121404aa2fbb640

commit_message:
Remove <py3.5 dependencies from requirements.txt

The requirements repo is support python 3.5 as oldest python version
while swift still supports py27.
Thus, requirements-check will fail on a couple of lines in
python-swiftclient.  The check is only run when these files are touched.

The py2.7 packagers we know about aren't depending on upstream
requirements.txt for correctness and aside from all the production
deployments running on py2.7 we only realistically support >=py3.7

There's no good reason for our requirements.txt to be "unspported" by
the openstack requirements check job.  Since they only support >=py3.5
we can change our requirements.txt inline with that.  This should be
fine for everything we could hope to get out of both our
requirements.txt and the check!

Change-Id: I3115eaf87a9d8e184bc5f9c650cf80250a842a0d

commit_message:
install venv_build_distro_package_list on venv_wheel_build_enable

This logic looks off, if you're going to do a build, you'd want the
build_distro packages installed right?

I'm missing a bunch of packages listed by *_devel_distro_packages
to complete the task "Install python packages into the venv"

Projects do this;

- name: Install the python venv
  import_role:
    name: "python_venv_build"
  vars:
    venv_build_distro_package_list: "{{ project_devel_distro_packages }}"

Change-Id: Ieeb5af76fb4fcb1c15d3926e1ad2946862495000

commit_message:
Update workspace tempest.conf on changes

When updating variables that would result in a modified
tempest.conf, the /root/.tempest/etc/tempest.conf or
/etc/tempest.conf would get updated properly.  A tempest
init happens after and does not copy those into an
existing workspace.  This change allows backup workspaces
to be kept on each modification to keep from loosing any
existing workspaces.

Change-Id: Id2de9cbd0f06b73dead5298afb857df2700bab60
Closes-Bug: #1763336
(cherry picked from commit 7654719383ad8a88db52e37564a8b9f9eaaca939)

commit_message:
Skip boostrap-ansible on upgrades if already run

Skips bootstrap-ansible on a rerun if it has already run
previously.

Moves the working directory creation to it's own function
so that the lock directory is created earlier.

Change-Id: I156e0143991c79cc2f664a98b6cd22353c01b55d
(cherry picked from commit e4ae0931f19242f947e463b41132826f83c5c278)

This change apply custom overrides set via environment settings to
leverage UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE, PIP_OPTS and GET_PIP_URL settings
for AIO.

Also we bring the two new environment variables INDEX_URL and
TRUSTED_HOST to override default PyPi index repos. The AIO bootstrap
use these variables to update/build PIP_OPTS vairable.

the Ic966bafd04c4c01b3d93851a0e3ec2c1f3312f28.

This change applies custom overrides set via environment settings to
leverage UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE, PIP_OPTS and GET_PIP_URL settings
for AIO.

Also, we add new environment variables PIP_PYPI_MIRROR,
PIP_WHEEL_MIRROR and PIP_MIRROR_HOST to override default PyPi index
repos. The AIO bootstrap leverages these variables to update/build
PIP_OPTS variable. These variables bring an ability to bootstrap
AIO on any CI, so later NODEPOOL_PYPI_MIRROR, NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST,
and NODEPOOL_WHEEL_MIRROR from the /etc/ci/mirror_info.sh could be
used to set them.

This change also include some fixes for the PIP_OPTS introduced in
the Ic966bafd04c4c01b3d93851a0e3ec2c1f3312f28.

Change-Id: Ic051173eb4d493c9201d9580becf8bab5ac18b45

AIO on any CI, so later NODEPOOL_PYPI_MIRROR, NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST,
and NODEPOOL_WHEEL_MIRROR from the /etc/ci/mirror_info.sh could be
used to set them.

This change also include some fixes for the PIP_OPTS introduced in
the Ic966bafd04c4c01b3d93851a0e3ec2c1f3312f28.

Change-Id: Ic051173eb4d493c9201d9580becf8bab5ac18b45

commit_message:
Add an ability to use custom PyPi index for deploy

This change adds an ability to use any external custom PyPi index
in the air-gapped environments to deploy OSA.

There are added three new environment variables - PIP_PYPI_MIRROR,
PIP_WHEEL_MIRROR and PIP_MIRROR_HOST to override default PyPi index
repos. The 'bootstrap-ansible.sh' and 'bootstrap-aio.sh' leverages
these variables to build/update the PIP_OPTS variable and also
creates '~/.pydistutils.cfg' file only if set and not empty.
The '~/.pydistutils.cfg' created from scratch with the settings
described in the Ie4ce336174aa2a825d125f7e0d9a256de139908b.

This is the second part of the changes which adds an ability to
deploy OAS in the air-gapped environments. The first one introduced
in the Iba750f6c91e7ca15267b728761ef41ecc4bf165f.

This change also include some fixes for the PIP_OPTS introduced in
the Ic966bafd04c4c01b3d93851a0e3ec2c1f3312f28.

Change-Id: Ic051173eb4d493c9201d9580becf8bab5ac18b45
(cherry picked from commit a60e85560d6db622576a67e6515ab658b691e3c3)
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Leverage the environment variables for the deploy

This change applies custom overrides set via environment settings to
leverage UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE and GET_PIP_URL already used in the
bootstrap-ansible.sh script. This will add an ability to deploy OSA
in the air-gapped environments because of hardcoded URLs pointed to
the git.openstack.org and bootstrap.pypa.io.

Change-Id: Iba750f6c91e7ca15267b728761ef41ecc4bf165f
Signed-off-by: Maksim Malchuk <maksim.malchuk@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit bdba1b199b1c829dae321866f5218e8426c2511a)

commit_message:
Change haproxy http-check expect for nova_console

Change the haproxy_backend_httpcheck_options to expect an 'OK' string
rather than a 200 response to avoid constant logging of broken pipe
errors in the console proxy services' logs.

Change-Id: I77b7e090aa4331e6a9547e0526a0f291f06a57c0
(cherry picked from commit dc409a98e3d8b3c28cc884442776bd9b525cc851)

commit_message:
Re-enable openSUSE Leap 15.0 aio_metal jobs

These jobs are currently passing and we want to keep them
passing. the _lxc jobs have currently no chance of succeeding
on leap 15.0 because networkd is not available here, so
removing them.

Change-Id: Iea81339907303f3840761a6ee1d89e6f46165f3c
(cherry picked from commit 51b035f50d71c0ffb255397667509abae290e735)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-06 18:29:11.000000000', 'message': "Remove vif_plugin_is_fatal and vif_plugin_timeout values

We are setting these values to False and 10 seconds
respectively and by default it is set to True and 300
seconds, which is the desirable because we don't want
and instance to boot if there was timeout to plug in a
VIF. Also, 10 seconds is a really short timeout for this

Change-Id: I4698d04e08fd0aa162c81d4a4af37a42e938d4f1
(cherry picked from commit 30952d23ec4a136db2fc741534172795c0086fac)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove vif_plugin_is_fatal and vif_plugin_timeout values

We are setting these values to False and 10 seconds
respectively and by default it is set to True and 300
seconds, which is the desirable because we don't want
and instance to boot if there was timeout to plug in a
VIF. Also, 10 seconds is a really short timeout for this

Change-Id: I4698d04e08fd0aa162c81d4a4af37a42e938d4f1
(cherry picked from commit 30952d23ec4a136db2fc741534172795c0086fac)

subject: Fix Glance NFS mount point ownership
messages:
[{'account_id': 29853, 'date': '2019-01-30 16:17:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-01-30 16:17:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-01-30 17:56:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-30 16:17:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Glance NFS mount point ownership

Glance NFS mounts are owned by `root` and are not writable by `glance`
user. Proposed change sets the `{{ glance_nfs_client.local_path }}`
directory ownership to
`{{ glance_system_user_name }}:{{ glance_system_group_name }}` so that
Glance can write to that.

Change-Id: I201aeca91442acffa12088c536389679ca2d8982
Closes-Bug: 1813300
Related-Bug: 1759552
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Glance NFS mount point ownership

Glance NFS mounts are owned by `root` and are not writable by `glance`
user. Proposed change sets the `{{ glance_nfs_client.local_path }}`
directory ownership to
`{{ glance_system_user_name }}:{{ glance_system_group_name }}` so that
Glance can write to that.

Change-Id: I201aeca91442acffa12088c536389679ca2d8982
Closes-Bug: 1813300
Related-Bug: 1759552

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-10-12 18:37:18.000000000', 'message': 'Migrate functional job to native zuulv3

The manilaclient functional test job
"manilaclient-dsvm-neutron-functional"
is currently broken due to a change to its
parent job in the devstack repository.

Instead of investing to fix that legacy style
job, we'd be better off rewriting it to be
in native zuulv3 style, i.e., without the
use of the deprecated devstack-gate project.

- Introduce a new job "python-manilaclient-functional"
  which replaces "manilaclient-dsvm-neutron-functional"
  but preserves the testing done by the latter.
- The new job runs on a minimal devstack (keystone,
  neutron, manila, mysql and rabbit) and uses an ansible
  role introduced to setup test configuration.
- Add a "bindep.txt" file to call out test system
  dependencies, and install them via the new job.
- Cleanup the old job, the associated devstack gate
  hooks and playbooks.

Change-Id: I3b67f3b566bdadf1cc228f885b7253435a4507b5
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit d65d7f05a7f99aad7b3a4ba286c8ab136775d303)
(cherry picked from commit f852358f21c04a551e40d397e00577fbb90aa534)
(cherry picked from commit cf01e725dfdccd37631c30400cb72d95ff275ecb)
(cherry picked from commit 771700bd513ec0c34225976b85835eafab7eb7b6)
'}, {'created': '2020-10-12 19:20:04.000000000', 'message': 'Migrate functional job to native zuulv3

commit_message:
Migrate functional job to native zuulv3

The manilaclient functional test job
"manilaclient-dsvm-neutron-functional"
is currently broken due to a change to its
parent job in the devstack repository.

Instead of investing to fix that legacy style
job, we'd be better off rewriting it to be
in native zuulv3 style, i.e., without the
use of the deprecated devstack-gate project.

- Introduce a new job "python-manilaclient-functional"
  which replaces "manilaclient-dsvm-neutron-functional"
  but preserves the testing done by the latter.
- The new job runs on a minimal devstack (keystone,
  neutron, manila, mysql and rabbit) and uses an ansible
  role introduced to setup test configuration.
- Add a "bindep.txt" file to call out test system
  dependencies, and install them via the new job.
- Cleanup the old job, the associated devstack gate
  hooks and playbooks.

Change-Id: I3b67f3b566bdadf1cc228f885b7253435a4507b5
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit d65d7f05a7f99aad7b3a4ba286c8ab136775d303)
(cherry picked from commit f852358f21c04a551e40d397e00577fbb90aa534)
(cherry picked from commit cf01e725dfdccd37631c30400cb72d95ff275ecb)
(cherry picked from commit 771700bd513ec0c34225976b85835eafab7eb7b6)
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add support for image_cache options

This patch introduces a new class named nova::compute::image_cache,
to support parameters in image_cache sections, which were recently
added into nova[1].

[1] 828e8047e5c8651ea757bda7922670889d5e8818

Change-Id: I61d81667e4c58b62c453e37072d9aef461923b46

commit_message:
Expose BlueStore

Explain how BlueStore vs traditional filesystems
are selected.

Improve config.yaml correspondingly. Move the
'bluestore' option's location in that file. Remove
blank lines for consistency.

Change-Id: Iebc21bdcac742a437719afb53f26729abbf8e87f

commit_message:
Do not manage /etc/ssl or /etc/pki directories or symlinks

For a metal deployment the keystone and horizon roles both try to
do this and it should be done in one place. This is moved to the
openstack_hosts role.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/757612
Change-Id: Iba607a89b104ef8a63c9f956e2cd60f6b7ca4466

subject: Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/victoria
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-25 08:39:12.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/victoria

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/victoria branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I5dc6c6bb904cc548de4e5c173329f95ade4ef52f
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/victoria

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/victoria branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I5dc6c6bb904cc548de4e5c173329f95ade4ef52f

commit_message:
Update master for stable/victoria

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/victoria.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/victoria.

Change-Id: Ib351f353652d487a47f8fe94de7853372e27dc99
Sem-Ver: feature

the same functionality as the one recently introduced into
puppet-nova[1].

commit_message:
Add skip_transfer_data parameter.

When performing the downtream upgrade from OSP15 to OSP16 we
don't require to run the tansfer data and hybrid_state step as
there is no Leapp upgrade that will wipe out the overcloud nodes.

This flag is set to false by default, so if we want to skip it
we need to implicitely specify it when running tripleo-upgrade.

Change-Id: I76434f225e8ff2680fbf4038912f64c776b20a18

We were using the operation (upgrade/update) to run the online db migrations
step. However, this step requires to run openstack overcloud external-upgrade run
only. As the tasks that take care of performing this operation are defined in
the external_upgrade_tasks section, which is triggered only if we call that
command. The call to openstack overcloud external-update run --tags online_upgrade
was not triggering any task at all.

Change-Id: I1ac71c8cc824f74898052c1587fa268836f5b4a7
'}]
commit_message:
Run external-upgrade for online db migrations.

We were using the operation (upgrade/update) to run the online db migrations
step. However, this step requires to run openstack overcloud external-upgrade run
only. As the tasks that take care of performing this operation are defined in
the external_upgrade_tasks section, which is triggered only if we call that
command. The call to openstack overcloud external-update run --tags online_upgrade
was not triggering any task at all.

Change-Id: I1ac71c8cc824f74898052c1587fa268836f5b4a7

[{'created': '2020-07-20 13:45:00.000000000', 'message': 'Add CADF notifications for federated keystone

Event notifications are useful for those that need to keep an audit
trail. Turned off by default as these logs contain user specific data
and local data protection laws should be considered.

Please see here for more information on CADF notifications:

commit_message:
Add CADF notifications for federated keystone

Event notifications are useful for those that need to keep an audit
trail. Turned off by default as these logs contain user specific data
and local data protection laws should be considered.
The default notificiation_opt_outs follow the keystone documentation.
Please see here for more information on CADF notifications:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/pike/advanced-topics/event_notifications.html

Change-Id: Id1867b6b50fc769757781eabc208ee9ead65f4c9

commit_message:
Use authorized_key module for key distribution

authorized_key module is part of ansible for a while and it fits perfectly
to the current scenario. So we can simplify process dramatically by
native module usage.

instance, during which volumes would be detached. So volumes
created by the boot task would be left. In fact, volumes should be
cleaned up.

This patch fixes this.

commit_message:
Clean up volumes on boot failure

When instance fails to spawn, nova would just shutdown
the instance, during which volumes would be detached.
If not retry,  volumes created by the boot task would
be left. In fact, volumes should be cleaned up.

This patch fixes this.

Change-Id: I877d8eff8d2fecde0cd16b01e80bff41bdb8d88a
Closes-Bug: #1699469

commit_message:
Simplify scheduler filter additions

Add 'nova_scheduler_extra_filters' to allow operators to enable
additional scheduler filters without overriding the entire list of
filters as in [0].

This also reduces the burden on ops to maintain the list of overridden
default schedulers because of things like [1].

[0] https://github.com/openstack/limestone-ci-cloud/blob/3886dbc40de036e7d1e3bb61917793d7067a89b2/openstack_deploy/user_variables.yml#L51-L69
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/596502/

Change-Id: I9ab6bcbef2b496df7f6ecf11a7d8f5f7891aeeca

commit_message:
Unblock queens (pep8, api doc, disable fedora_latest)

Fix various pep8 issues.
Blacklist the bandit warning B105 (there is a follow-up
change which fixes those issues, but it may be not needed
on this branch).

Also disable the fedora-latest job, which has been broken
for a while and need some work (starting with the usage
of a still supported version of Fedora).

This change is a combination of two different fixes
that need to land together.

No cherry-pick conflicts are present after the backport.

Co-Authored-By: pengyuesheng <pengyuesheng@gohighsec.com>
Co-Authored-By: Ghanshyam Mann <gmann@ghanshyammann.com>

(cherry picked from commit bf95c37b84688c99bda0849230508d955fc62f82)
(cherry picked from commit 367453b54319b90d2660013a98b15cbd9e0c0846)
(cherry picked from commit 9314499b2b952c916bfe29ec9233815073ee3d27)

(cherry picked from commit a1cd623644964c832641b24c06e0f8799fdb3e0b)

Change-Id: I97a858b33b48821d1e886248e2a6a2bb81c5b941

commit_message:
Fix coverage job

`coverage run pytest` runs coverage against the tests in a file called
"pytest", whereas `coverage run -m pytest` uses pytest as the test
runner, which is what we really want here.

To avoid duplicated maitenance of pytest arguments,
unit_tests.sh is updated to handle the coverage run.

Co-Authored-By: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I106cb5227ca8c4f0a6f9d81c37e745a6f304de45

commit_message:
Add new nagios check for vault health

Improved check_vault_version.py to also
check whether vault is sealed, therefore
renaming it to check_vault_health.py.

Registered the new check with NRPE and
removed the old one.

The alert of vault being sealed takes
precedence over version checking.

Closes-bug: #1856025
Change-Id: I9b5ec739d27f35b793e91f61f070995105f80d06

commit_message:
add py38 in tox.ini

in 'victoria' cycle, we should test py38 by default.

Trigger uwsgi restart

When we were migrating service to uwsgi usage, we clean forgot to
trigger uwsgi restart on service config change.

commit_message:
Fix vip handling for standalone and undercloud

If we have duplicated addresses between the ctlplane ip and the defined
vips, we don't want to configure them. This change makes the vips
optional in the network config.

Change-Id: I1d09dff2736a4fbc10fcc8a9db0d4391cd76684b
Related-Bug: #1895822
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/756706/

commit_message:
Add address groups to callbacks resources

This change adds the address groups as a resource for callbacks. This
resource definition is used when the ML2 plugin pushes notifications to
the agents.

Thanks gmann for this PoC, I used this as base for adding similar plugin for neutron (https://review.opendev.org/731554)'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2020-05-28 18:37:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Are we going to treat this as part of our regular API, with api-ref documentation and everything? If so, the fact that the response on /healthcheck varies depending on the configured backend would be problematic, no? Also, it would have to be versioned.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-05-28 22:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

Awesome work gmann, thank you for proving this out. Some preliminary comments and question inline.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-05-28 23:39:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2020-05-29 12:56:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-05-29 14:34:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

As I said before, I don't think it's reasonable to be spraying MQ connections or messages, or DB connections or queries in response to an unauthenticated health check. I think we can populate stats on authenticated requests that get reported by the healthcheck stuff and still accomplish a lot of that goal. Meaning, instrument nova.context to keep some details which we report there.

However, from a higher view, I think this is doing way too much for the intent of the healthchecks, unless I'm massively misunderstanding what the goal of those really are. I believe the point is to have them report "is this API worker healthy" and not "is the whole of this Nova deployment healthy". IIUC, the desire is to provide something for the load balancer to hit quite frequently that lets it know if the API worker needs to be pulled out of rotation, or in the case of k8s, killed and restarted somewhere else. In that case, something far lighter would be just fine I think. Gating the healthy status on "have I been able to connect to any MQ in the last ten requests" (and the same for a database) would be fine. We could also keep stats per DB and per MQ when we go to do it, and report those. Something like "10/10 times I was asked to connect to cell7 I failed" would indicate that the cell isn't reachable or something maybe.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-05-29 15:23:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-05-29 15:24:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Are we going to treat this as part of our regular API, with api-ref
 > documentation and everything? If so, the fact that the response on
 > /healthcheck varies depending on the configured backend would be
 > problematic, no? Also, it would have to be versioned.

That is good question, I think making it API versioning (microversion) is diffcult. Amy be date based version like metadata API is one option like Melanie mentioned. this is something we can disucss more.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-05-29 17:39:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2020-05-29 17:44:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-05-29 18:32:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-05-29 20:38:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-05-29 20:43:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-05-29 20:52:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-06-01 15:23:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-06-01 15:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-06-01 15:49:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2020-06-02 01:50:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2020-06-02 02:33:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-06-02 15:02:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6476, 'date': '2020-06-02 15:48:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi,

With my operator hat on, I very much agree with what Dan wrote. On a typical deployment I make, the nova-api would get 3x /heatlcheck requests per seconds (because I deploy 3 haproxy with a VIP, and each of them checks for the nova-api). In such context, the /healthcheck must reply fast, and be as lightweight as possible.

Also, let's say there's an issue with the db or RabbitMQ. Chances are that all of the 3 nova-api that the haproxies are trying to reach all see the same issue. As a consequence, all of the 3 haproxy wont see any of the nova-api as working, and therefore, will mark all of them as non-healthy. Final result: the 3 haproxies will all have no nova-api to connect to, and will return a 503 error on all queries to nova-api. From the operator stand point, this really isn't what we want to do...

Now, if nova-api is able to provide URLs of the form /monitoring/db or /monitoring/cell/7, then that's great, and we'll use them with zabbix. But not at all for haproxy to take a decision.

Finally, by all means, do *NOT* throw away this very nice code. It *WILL* be useful to operators. Just bind it to a different URL than /healthcheck (as per my suggestion above, for example)."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-06-02 23:40:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-06-04 19:53:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Note for gmann after the PTG discussion today:

Here's the spot in the code that Dan and I were talking about, the target_cell context manager:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/context.py#L395

where after yielding, we could populate info in our global CELL_LAST_SUCCESS cache (or whatever name) variable with success/fail info. This will organically populate while auth'ed users access the system.

Then, when an unauth'ed request comes to /healthcheck, we just take a look in nova.context.CELL_LAST_SUCCESS and return 200 or 503 depending on what we see in there. That is the basic idea. We can explore format/what to store in CELL_LAST_SUCCESS as implementation details during code review."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2020-06-04 20:18:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Note for gmann after the PTG discussion today:
 > 
 > Here's the spot in the code that Dan and I were talking about, the
 > target_cell context manager:
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/context.py#L395
 > 
 > where after yielding, we could populate info in our global
 > CELL_LAST_SUCCESS cache (or whatever name) variable with
 > success/fail info.

After I wrote this I realized this doesn't cover DB accesses that occur via a set_target_cell only (and don't use the target_cell context manager). And it also doesn't cover MQ accesses. When we target_cell, we aren't actually connecting to the DB or MQ yet. We are only just setting up what to use when we do try to connect soon after at the DB layer and the RPC layer.

So it seems we need a different approach...

Just to throw out some initial thoughts:

The cached cell DB connections occur here when the using() method is called [1]. So I'm wondering if maybe we could make a decorator that try-except and populates nova.context.CELL_LAST_SUCCESS based on whether using() returns or raises.

The cell MQ connections we prepare here for each communication [2] but I suspect the connection attempt doesn't happen until we call() or cast() [3], so that ... is not looking easy for decorating everything. At first glance, it seems like we'd want to wrap the call() and cast() in a new helper method in nova/rpc.py and decorate only those.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L183-L253
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/rpc.py#L437-L446
[3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/compute/rpcapi.py#L525"}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-10-02 15:54:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> > Note for gmann after the PTG discussion today:
 > >
 > > Here's the spot in the code that Dan and I were talking about,
 > the
 > > target_cell context manager:
 > >
 > > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/context.py#L395
 > >
 > > where after yielding, we could populate info in our global
 > > CELL_LAST_SUCCESS cache (or whatever name) variable with
 > > success/fail info.
 > 
 > After I wrote this I realized this doesn't cover DB accesses that
 > occur via a set_target_cell only (and don't use the target_cell
 > context manager). And it also doesn't cover MQ accesses. When we
 > target_cell, we aren't actually connecting to the DB or MQ yet. We
 > are only just setting up what to use when we do try to connect soon
 > after at the DB layer and the RPC layer.
 > 
 > So it seems we need a different approach...
 > 
 > Just to throw out some initial thoughts:
 > 
 > The cached cell DB connections occur here when the using() method
 > is called [1]. So I'm wondering if maybe we could make a decorator
 > that try-except and populates nova.context.CELL_LAST_SUCCESS based
 > on whether using() returns or raises.
 > 
 > The cell MQ connections we prepare here for each communication [2]
 > but I suspect the connection attempt doesn't happen until we call()
 > or cast() [3], so that ... is not looking easy for decorating
 > everything. At first glance, it seems like we'd want to wrap the
 > call() and cast() in a new helper method in nova/rpc.py and
 > decorate only those.

I looked into the RPC part of this a bit today. I simply killed the rabbit process to trigger an error for a POST servers/{serverid}/remote-consoles REST request. The message bus connection does happen at the call() method call, but that call does not raise an exception back if the connection fails. Oslo messaging retries the call forever (at least in devstack with default config). Eventually the http client timeouts but the server side doesn't. I saw the same for cast() method too. 

When I started the rabbit then the nova RPC call() returned an oslo_messaging.exceptions.MessagingTimeout exception to the nova code. 

Is there any oslo messaging configuration that makes this behavior better? If not the our simple logic to check for failed rpc calls will not work as the failed call will only be detected _after_ the message bus recovered. 

 > 
 > [1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L183-L253
 > [2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/rpc.py#L437-L446
 > [3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/8988316b8c132c9662dea6cf0345975e87ce7344/nova/compute/rpcapi.py#L525"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-10-05 13:38:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Is there any oslo messaging configuration that makes this behavior
 > better? If not the our simple logic to check for failed rpc calls
 > will not work as the failed call will only be detected _after_ the
 > message bus recovered.

If we update the status timestamp every time we get a successful response, then we can say "it's working if it's less than a minute old" and "we don't know if it's working" otherwise.

Setting a failure flag if we get a MessagingTimeout helps us know if there's a failing *remote* service, but that's not really what we should be reporting, IMHO. Meaning, the service health of a single nova-api worker should not be impacted by a remote compute being down.

It's been a while since we had this conversation, but I believe my point was that we can say something about health being good if there is recent success, and say "unknown" or "assume it's bad" if there isn't. Unless we can hook into o.msg's connection loop or have them provide us a connection health status, that's the least-impactful thing we can do, which I think is important.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-10-07 09:34:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-10-07 09:36:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > Is there any oslo messaging configuration that makes this
 > behavior
 > > better? If not the our simple logic to check for failed rpc calls
 > > will not work as the failed call will only be detected _after_
 > the
 > > message bus recovered.
 > 
 > If we update the status timestamp every time we get a successful
 > response, then we can say "it's working if it's less than a minute
 > old" and "we don't know if it's working" otherwise.
 > 
 > Setting a failure flag if we get a MessagingTimeout helps us know
 > if there's a failing *remote* service, but that's not really what
 > we should be reporting, IMHO. Meaning, the service health of a
 > single nova-api worker should not be impacted by a remote compute
 > being down.
 > 
 > It's been a while since we had this conversation, but I believe my
 > point was that we can say something about health being good if
 > there is recent success, and say "unknown" or "assume it's bad" if
 > there isn't. Unless we can hook into o.msg's connection loop or
 > have them provide us a connection health status, that's the
 > least-impactful thing we can do, which I think is important.

PS2 now tries to implement your suggestion. Unfortunately the middleware cannot returns "Unknown" health state. It is binary. So the current patch is not useful for haproxy usage.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-10-07 09:38:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-10-07 10:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29963, 'date': '2020-10-07 10:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

When service is up and populates the cache with status then healthchecks will start returning the actual status.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-10-08 13:46:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-28 03:23:44.000000000', 'message': "PoC: nova healthchecks API

To know nova is healthy or not, the new API endpoint
/healthcheck is provided.

healthchecks is based on configurable plugins which can
perform various checks.

oslo provides two basic plugins which does file back health checks
instead of real checks on things are up or not. These can be
used for HAProxy etc [1]:
- disable_by_file
- disable_by_files_ports

Nova provides three plugins:
1. Nova_DB_healthcheck: Checks if API, cell0 and at least one cell DB
  is up. If so then return Healthy otherwise Unhealthy
2. Nova_MQ_healthcheck: Checks if at least one cells MQ
  is up. If so then return Healthy otherwise Unhealthy
3. Nova_services_healthcheck: Checks if at least one cell has at least
  one conductor and one compute service running. If so then return
  Healthy otherwise Unhealthy

Response will return the dict of API|cell's DB|MQ|services with their status.

Flow digrame and detailed response example
- https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/nova-healthchecks

TODO: Auth part for various plugins
TODO: extend the service checks

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.middleware/latest/reference/healthcheck_plugins.html#available-plugins

Change-Id: I3fa1667cb2570303d166453a2d10a3c146b6606f
"}, {'created': '2020-10-07 09:34:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add nova healthcheck API

This patch adds a lightweight RPC healthcheck to the nova API.

This healthcheck returns OK if there was a recent successful RPC call or
cast from the API worker that handling the healthcheck request. In the
other hand if the API worker did not handle any requests since startup
or the last successful request is older than [default]/service_down_time
then the healthcheck return NOK.

Please note that the above behavior this healthcheck cannot be used from
haproxy as a freshly restarted nova-api service would report it health
as NOT OK until the first API request is forwarded to it. But haproxy
would not forward any request to this nova-api as its health is NOT OK.
Also if an API worker would not get API request for a while then its
health would switch to NOT OK and therefore haproxy will never send any
new request to this worker.

In the healthcheck middleware a healthcheck result is a boolean so we
cannot model that the health of a service is unknown.

Co-Authored-By: Ghanshyam Mann <gmann@ghanshyammann.com>

Change-Id: I3fa1667cb2570303d166453a2d10a3c146b6606f
'}]
commit_message:
Add nova healthcheck API

This patch adds a lightweight RPC healthcheck to the nova API.

This healthcheck returns OK if there was a recent successful RPC call or
cast from the API worker that handling the healthcheck request. In the
other hand if the API worker did not handle any requests since startup
or the last successful request is older than [default]/service_down_time
then the healthcheck return NOK.

Please note that the above behavior this healthcheck cannot be used from
haproxy as a freshly restarted nova-api service would report it health
as NOT OK until the first API request is forwarded to it. But haproxy
would not forward any request to this nova-api as its health is NOT OK.
Also if an API worker would not get API request for a while then its
health would switch to NOT OK and therefore haproxy will never send any
new request to this worker.

In the healthcheck middleware a healthcheck result is a boolean so we
cannot model that the health of a service is unknown.

Co-Authored-By: Ghanshyam Mann <gmann@ghanshyammann.com>

Change-Id: I3fa1667cb2570303d166453a2d10a3c146b6606f

to 172.29.236.9/32 to be the same in all part of the document.

Closes-Bug: #1773793

commit_message:
Explicitly enable/disable active/active

As deployers may have usecases with several different backends being
served with the same cinder volume,
we should provide an option to easily override default behaviour

Change-Id: Idc9a71d722b7443cf1437c2d95f75c615b6035a4
(cherry picked from commit c6b9f011b777aa0513e99a35fba7d976a4c9d4c1)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-09-08 13:40:10.000000000', 'message': 'Lazily cache parsed value of list/json parameters

Parsing the value of JSON parameters at the time we create them (or
update the default value) results in exceptions occurring while creating
the Stack object, that are then not caught and transformed. The result
is an HTTP 500 Internal Error reported by the API, with an unhelpful
error message.

By not parsing the JSON until it is needed, we ensure that any errors
will occur during validation, where errors are appropriately transformed
(to StackValidationFailed) and annotated with the necessary information
to help the user determine the source.

Change-Id: I70e341c344d6254173ad4519276626230087263a
Story: 2007957
Task: 40443
(cherry picked from commit b603470a1207fcbc9ee30f3a3b4b457a9f83a03a)
'}]
commit_message:
Lazily cache parsed value of list/json parameters

Parsing the value of JSON parameters at the time we create them (or
update the default value) results in exceptions occurring while creating
the Stack object, that are then not caught and transformed. The result
is an HTTP 500 Internal Error reported by the API, with an unhelpful
error message.

By not parsing the JSON until it is needed, we ensure that any errors
will occur during validation, where errors are appropriately transformed
(to StackValidationFailed) and annotated with the necessary information
to help the user determine the source.

Change-Id: I70e341c344d6254173ad4519276626230087263a
Story: 2007957
Task: 40443
(cherry picked from commit b603470a1207fcbc9ee30f3a3b4b457a9f83a03a)

Trigger uwsgi restart

When we were migrating service to uwsgi usage, we clean forgot to
trigger uwsgi restart on service config change.

commit_message:
Move provider_networks module into os_neutron

This change is to delete the provider_networks module from this repo
because it has been moved into the os_neutron repo. This will make the
role much more independent and self-contained as the module will live,
be called from and access vars within os_neutron.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/658126/
